openconnector

Interface Connector

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractConnector

    public interface Connector
    A Connector serves as a common interface for low-level communication to a resource. The methods in this interface fits into one of the following categories:

    • Connector capabilities: These provide information about what types of objects a connector can manage with and which features are supported for each object type. These are the only methods that do not require a fully configured connector.
      • getSupportedObjectTypes()
      • getSupportedFeatures(String)
    • Connector Lifecycle: A connector is stateful, in that it must be configured before it can be used and eventually closed. These methods define that lifecycle.
      • configure(ConnectorConfig, Log)
      • setObjectType(String)
      • close()
    • Connector Utilities: These methods test a connector.
      • testConnection()
      • discoverSchema(String)
      • authenticate(String, String)
    • Object access: These method allows you to create, update, and delete resource objects.
      • read(String)
      • iterate(Filter)
      • provision(Plan)

    A Connector MUST implement all "Connector Capabilities" method, "Connector Lifecycle" methods, and the testConnection(). All other methods are optional. If supported, a method should be declared as supported by returning the appropriate Feature from getSupportedFeatures(String). Otherwise, the method should throw and UnsupportedOperationException. Rather than implementing the Connector interface directly, it is recommended that the AbstractConnector be extended.

    As mentioned previously, Connectors are stateful, in that they must be configured, used, and closed. The connector keeps state about how it was configured, dynamic settings such as object type, and any internal connection state to the underlying resource. Every caller must take care to close the Connector to release any resources. Here is a typical pattern for using a Connector: 

       Connector conn = new MyConnector();
   try {
       conn.configure(config, log);
       Map<String,Object> account = conn.read("myaccountid");
   }
   finally {
       conn.close();
   }

    Object Types

    A Connector declares what types of objects it can manage through getSupportedObjectTypes. These are typically either accounts or groups (see the OBJECT_TYPE_* constants), but a connector can claim support for other non-standard types (for example - roles, etc...). The default object type for a new connector is OBJECT_TYPE_ACCOUNT. You can change the object type by calling setObjectType Once set, the object type influences the behavior of the read and iterate methods.

    Data

    Resource objects (accounts, groups, etc.) are modeled as Maps with the map keys representing the object attribute names. Map values will usually be String or List<String> but they can be of any type defined by Schema.Type. When you build a Plan, the values in the plan should match what is expected by the connector. Though it is recommended that connectors do type coercion this is not required.

    Configuration

    Each connector will require different configuration information that dictates how to connect to the resource and specifics about connector behavior. This information is defined in the ConnectorConfig. The configuration should include a list of Schema objects defining the attributes of each of the objects that are managed by the connector. Schemas are optional for simple connectors in which the object schemas are fixed.

    Exceptions

    The connector methods will either throw an UnsupportedOperationException, a checked exception that indicates an expected error condition (such as ObjectNotFoundException), or a generic unchecked exception that indicates some other type of resource failure (ConnectorException).

    • Field Detail

      • OBJECT_TYPE_ACCOUNT

        static final java.lang.String OBJECT_TYPE_ACCOUNT
        Object type representing an account on a resource.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • OBJECT_TYPE_GROUP

        static final java.lang.String OBJECT_TYPE_GROUP
        Object type representing an group on a resource.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • OBJECT_TYPE_TICKET

        static final java.lang.String OBJECT_TYPE_TICKET
        Object type representing an group on a resource.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ATT_PASSWORD

        static final java.lang.String ATT_PASSWORD
        A reserved attribute name used to convey an account password. This is a write-only attribute, connectors are not expected to return this from a read().
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ATT_DISABLED

        static final java.lang.String ATT_DISABLED
        A reserved attribute name used to convey disabled status. Setting this to true disables the object, false enables the object. Connectors are also expected to return this in the Map returned by the read() method to convey the current status.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ATT_LOCKED

        static final java.lang.String ATT_LOCKED
        A reserved attribute name used to convey lock status. Setting this to true locks the object, false unlocks the object. Note that most connectors only allow you to unlock objects, locking is done as a side effect of some other action, such as failing to supply a correct password.

        Connectors are also expected to return this in the Map returned by the read() method to convey the current status.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ATT_PERMISSIONS

        static final java.lang.String ATT_PERMISSIONS
        A reserved attribute name used to pass a List of Permission objects.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ATT_DELETED

        static final java.lang.String ATT_DELETED
        A reserved attribute name used to indiciate that this object has been deleted. This is set only when doing delta aggregation and the connector supports detection of native deletes.

        Note that ResourceObject has a few other flags for special situations like incomplete, incremental, remove, and missing. These were only used by SMConnector and are not expected to be applicable for OpenConnectors.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARG_EXPIRATION

        static final java.lang.String ARG_EXPIRATION
        An argument that can be passed in the Item for the ATT_PASSWORD attribute to indicate that the password should expire. This is expected to be a java.util.Date.
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARG_CURRENT

        static final java.lang.String ARG_CURRENT
        An argument that can be passed in the Item for ATT_PASSWORD that contains what is believed to be the current password. This should be passed from above if the resource requires the current password in order to change the password.

        In theory this could be used for other attributes besides passwords.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • ARG_PARTITION

        static final java.lang.String ARG_PARTITION
        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

    • Method Detail

      • getSupportedObjectTypes

        java.util.List<java.lang.String> getSupportedObjectTypes()
        Return a list of the object types supported by this connector. This list can contain any of the OBJECT_TYPE_* constants or any arbitrary type that is supported by the connector.

      • getSupportedFeatures

        java.util.List<Connector.Feature> getSupportedFeatures(java.lang.String objectType)
        Return the list of Features that are supported for the given object type. If a Feature is returned, the corresponding method should not throw an UnsupportedOperationException for the given object type.

      • configure

        void configure(ConnectorConfig config,
               Log log)
        throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Configure the connector with connection parameters and optional schemas. Once configured you select the desired target object type by calling setObjectType. The default object type after configuration is OBJECT_TYPE_ACCOUNT.
        Parameters:
        config - The ConnectorConfig that specifies connection parameters and schemas.
        log - An implementation of Log that the connector can use for logging.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If config is null.

      • setObjectType

        void setObjectType(java.lang.String objectType)
            throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Change the target object type for connector methods. The default object type after initial configuration is OBJECT_TYPE_ACCOUNT. This will influence the behavior of the read() and iterate() methods.
        Parameters:
        objectType - The target object type for future method calls. This can be one of the OBJECT_TYPE_* constants or any supported object type.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - If type is null.

        Returns:
        the current target object type.

        Returns:
        the ConnectorServices object.

      • close

        void close()
        Close the underlying resources that are being held by this connector. Clients MUST call this when they are done with a connector or else there can be resource leaks.

      • testConnection

        void testConnection()
             throws ConnectorException
        Test the configured to see if a connection can be made. This should throw exceptions if the configuration is not complete, has invalid values, the resource cannot be contacted. If the connection succeeds, no exceptions are thrown.
        Throws:
        ConnectorException

               throws ConnectorException,
                      java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Discover the Schema for the currently configured object type.
        Throws:
        ConnectorException - If the operation fails.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If the DISCOVER_SCHEMA feature is not supported.

      • read

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> read(java.lang.String id)
                                               throws ConnectorException,
                                                      ObjectNotFoundException,
                                                      java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Return the object of the configured object type that has the given native identifier.
        Parameters:
        id - A unique identifier for the object.
        Returns:
        The object that was read from the resource, or null if an object with the given id was not found.
        Throws:
        ConnectorException - If the operation fails.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If the GET feature is not supported.
        ObjectNotFoundException

      • iterate

        java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> iterate(Filter filter)
                                                                      throws ConnectorException,
                                                                             java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Return an iterator over the objects of the configured object type that match the given filter (or all objects if no filter is specified).
        Parameters:
        filter - The possibly null filter to use to constrain which objects are returned.
        Returns:
        An iterator over the object of the configured object type that match the given filter.
        Throws:
        ConnectorException - If the operation fails.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If the ITERATE feature is not supported.

      • getIteratorPartitions

        java.util.List<Partition> getIteratorPartitions(int suggestedPartitionCount,
                                                Filter filter,
                                                java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> ops)
                                         throws ConnectorException,
                                                java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Return the list of partitions for a connector.

        The partitions returned here simple objects that hold a name, size, objectType and an attributes map for additional information.

        The caller will take each partition and treat it as a single unit of work that will be distributed among the cluster of servers and or threads.

        Each object in the list should contain enough about the partition so the calls to iterateObjects have information to process a single partition.

        A unique name (within the list) and the objectType is required to be returned with each partition.

        The caller will give hints to the suggestedPartitionCount based on processors and cores but the Application config should ultimately determine how many partitions should be returned.

        Parameters:
        suggestedPartitionCount - The caller will calculate the optimal number of partitions and pass it into the connector.
        filter - The possibly null filter to help constrain which options are returned.
        ops - The possibly null map will provides additional options for future expansion.
        Returns:
        List of Objects used to configure each partition, returning
        Throws:
        ConnectorException
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        See Also:
        Partition

      • iterate

        java.util.Iterator<java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object>> iterate(Partition parition)
                                                                      throws ConnectorException,
                                                                             java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Method used to iterate over the object in chunks that can be processed in different threads or machine pools.
        Parameters:
        parition - One of the objects built in getIteratorPartitions that will drive which objects get returned by the iterator.
        Returns:
        Iterator over the object for a Partition
        Throws:
        ConnectorException
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        See Also:
        Partition

      • authenticate

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> authenticate(java.lang.String identity,
                                                              java.lang.String password)
                                                       throws ConnectorException,
                                                              AuthenticationFailedException,
                                                              ExpiredPasswordException,
                                                              ObjectNotFoundException,
                                                              java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Attempt to authenticate to the underlying resource using the given identity and password. The identity may be the value of the identity attribute, but could also be a value that can be used to search for the account (for example - sAMAccountName, full name, etc...). If successful, this returns the account that was authenticated to.
        Parameters:
        identity - A value for an identifying attribute of the account to authenticate with.
        password - The password to use to authenticate.
        Returns:
        The authenticated account if authentication was successful.
        Throws:
        ConnectorException - If the operation fails.
        AuthenticationFailedException - If authentication failed.
        ExpiredPasswordException - If authentication failed because of an expired password.
        ObjectNotFoundException - If an object that matches the given identity could not be found.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If the AUTHENTICATE feature is not supported.

      • authenticate

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> authenticate(java.lang.String accountId,
                                                              java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.lang.Object> options)
                                                       throws ConnectorException,
                                                              AuthenticationFailedException,
                                                              ExpiredPasswordException,
                                                              ObjectNotFoundException,
                                                              java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Attempt to authenticate to the underlying resource using the given accountId and password. The accountId may be the value of the identity attribute, but could also be a value that can be used to search for the account (for example - sAMAccountName, full name, etc...). If successful, this returns the account that was authenticated to.
        Parameters:
        accountId - A value for an identifying attribute of the account to authenticate with.
        options - Additional options to consider during authentication including the password.
        Returns:
        The authenticated account if authentication was successful.
        Throws:
        ConnectorException - If the operation fails.
        AuthenticationFailedException - If authentication failed.
        ExpiredPasswordException - If authentication failed because of an expired password.
        ObjectNotFoundException - If an object that matches the given identity could not be found.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If the AUTHENTICATE feature is not supported.

      • provision

        void provision(Plan plan)
        throws ConnectorException,
               java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Evaluate a provisioning plan that specifies operations to be performed on one or more objects. The plan is expected to be modified as a side effect and contain one or more Result objects.
        Parameters:
        plan - The plan to evaluate.
        Throws:
        ConnectorException - If the operation fails.
        ObjectAlreadyExistsException - If an object already exists on the resource.
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException - If the an operation in the plan is not supported.

      • checkStatus

        Result checkStatus(java.lang.String id)
            throws ConnectorException,
                   ObjectNotFoundException,
                   java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException
        Using the id passed into this method check the request to see if has completed.

        This method will be called one time for each ProvisioningResult returned in the ProvisioningPlan during provisioning. The provision method can store results at either the plan, account request or the attribute request level.

        The new status, returned result's errors, and warnings will be merged back into the main project.

        Returning a null result will have no change on the request and it will remained queued.

        Parameters:
        id -
        Returns:
        Result
        Throws:
        ConnectorException
        ObjectNotFoundException
        java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException

        Returns:
        true, if connector supports partitioned delta aggregation

      • setStatisticsCollector

        void setStatisticsCollector(connector.common.statisticscollector.StatisticsCollector statisticsCollector)
        Set the StatisticsCollector object require for underlying connector to push the aggreagtion statistics. The Object resposible for pushing the aggreagtion statistical data. This is cross cutting concern of recording the statistics which will help in analysis of aggregation performance.
